facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 516 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the order dated September 20, 1962, of the Central Government Labour Court at Dhanbad in Application No. L. C. 113 of 1962.

facts.text: The respondent was in the service of the appellant-bank's branch at Calcutta and worked as an assistant cashier.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was in the service of the appellant-banks branch at Calcutta and worked as an assistant cashier.

facts.text: On June 17, 1961, one Shankerlal applied for telegraphic transfer of Rs. 4,000/- from Calcutta to Sujangarh and handed over currency notes of Rs. 100/each to the respondent.

facts.text: Shankerlal remembered that he had given 41 notes instead of 40 to the respondent and requested him to return the bundle of notes for verification.

anchor.surface_text: As the respondent was counting the notes, Shankerlal remembered that he had given 41 notes instead of 40 to the respondent

facts.text: The respondent refused to return the notes saying that the amount given to him was Rs. 4,000/- and notes Rs. 4,100/-

anchor.surface_text: The respondent however refused to return the notes saying that the amount given to him was Rs. 4,000/- and notes Rs. 4,100/-

facts.text: Shankerlal verified that he had taken 41 notes instead of 40 and had thus handed over one note of Rs. 100/- extra to the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Shankerlal went back to his shop and verified that he had taken 41 notes instead of 40 and had thus handed over one note

facts.text: Shankerlal complained to the Manager about this.

anchor.surface_text: He then came back to the bank and complained to the Manager about this.

facts.text: The manager ordered the chief cashier to close the cash in the hands of the respondent and to check the amount in his hand with the books.

anchor.surface_text: The manager ordered the chief cashier to close the cash in the hands of the respondent and to check the amount in his hand

facts.text: The chief cashier found on checking that there was one note of Rs. 100/- extra with the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The chief cashier found on checking that there was one note of Rs. 100/- extra with the respondent.

facts.text: The manager asked the respondent to hand over the extra note but the respondent refused to do so saying that it belonged to him.

facts.text: In explanation he said that it had been given to him by his mother.

anchor.surface_text: In explanation he said that it had been given to him by his mother.

facts.text: The manager deputed the chief cashier along with another person to the respondent's house to make necessary inquiries.

anchor.surface_text: The manager immediately took steps to verify this statement and deputed the chief cashier along with another person to the

facts.text: Both his mother and father said that they had not given a hundred-rupee note to the respondent.

facts.text: The respondent then came out with another story that the note was given to him by a tenant of the building in which he lived. He gave out the name of the tenant as Mondal.

facts.text: It was found that there was no person of the name of Mondal in that building.

facts.text: The bank decided to take disciplinary proceedings against the respondent and handed over a charge-sheet to him. The respondent was also suspended from the bank's service.

anchor.surface_text: The bank therefore decided to take disciplinary proceedings against the respondent and handed over a charge- sheet to him

facts.text: An enquiry was conducted against the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter an enquiry was conducted against the respondent.

facts.text: The enquiry officer came to the conclusion that the two charges framed against the respondent had been proved.

anchor.surface_text: The enquiry officer came to the conclusion that the two charges framed against the respondent had been proved and reco

facts.text: The enquiry officer recommended discharge from the service of the bank after taking into consideration the past service and conduct of the respondent.

facts.text: After this application was made, the bank actually discharged the respondent on January 15, 1962.

issues.text: whether the labour court was right in holding that the application under s.33(2)(b) was not maintainable because it had been made for approval of the proposed action before the actual discharge

anchor.surface_text: an application under s. 33 2  b  would not be maintainable The present appeal by special leave is against this order of the labour court. The main contention of the appellant is that the labour court was not right in holding that the application was not maintainable on the ground that it had been made for approval of the proposed action and not after the action had been taken.

issues.text: the question whether approval should be granted to the action proposed to be taken by the appellant-bank

anchor.surface_text: The view of the labour court therefore that the application by the appellant in the present case was not maintainable must fail. This brings us to the question whether approval should be granted to the action proposed to be taken by the appellant-bank.

arguments.claim: Application under s.33(2)(b) not maintainable as made for approval of proposed discharge before actual discharge

anchor.surface_text: That court held relying on a decision of this Court in Strawboard Manufacturing Co. Gobind 1  that as the application had been made for approval of the proposed discharge and before the actual discharge of the respondent, it was not maintainable. Consequently it dismissed the bank's prayer for approval of the proposed action.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ions companytained in s. 33  2   b . We are therefore of opinion that the labour companyrt was wrong in holding that an application made by an employe

arguments.court_reasoning: Misunderstood Strawboard; s.33(2)(b) permits application before action taken

arguments.claim: Labour court erred in holding application not maintainable; Strawboard case misunderstood by labour court

anchor.surface_text: The present appeal by special leave is against this order of the labour court. The main contention of the appellant is that the labour court was not right in holding that the application was not maintainable on the ground that it had been made for approval of the proposed action and not after the action had been taken. It is urged that the decision of this Court in Strawboard Manufacturing Co.s, case 1  has been misunderstood by the labour court and this Court did not lay down in that case that an application under s. 33 2  b  would not be maintainable if it is made by an employer after he had concluded the enquiry and decided to impose a certain punishment but had not actually imposed it.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: s number entertainable and that such an application must necessarily be made after the action of which approval is sought is taken. All that the Straw

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed; elaborated correct interpretation of Strawboard

arguments.claim: Strawboard case negatived requirement to apply before action; did not prohibit application for proposed action before actual dismissal

anchor.surface_text: The contention in the Strawboard Manufacturing Co.s case 1  was that the application for approval must be made before the employer takes action and that view was negatived. In that case what the employer had done was to make the enquiry and decide to dismiss the employee. The order of dismissal was passed on February 1, 1960 and on the same day an application was made to the tribunal for approval of the action taken.

arguments.claim: s.33(2)(b) does not require application only after action taken; application for proposed action before actual action maintainable

anchor.surface_text: But there is nothing in s. 33  2   b  which requires that an application for approval can only be made after the action has been taken. We see nothing in principle against the employer making an application under s. 33  2   b  for approval of the proposed action before the actual action is taken. Such a course on the part of the employer would, if anything, be more favourable to the employee and would not in our opinion be against the provisions contained in s. 33  2   b .

arguments.claim: Matter should be remanded to labour court as respondent ill and could not appear

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the respondent prays that in the circumstances the matter should be remanded to the labour court to enable the respondent to appear. We find however that the respondent had filed a written statement in reply to the banks application in which he controverted the facts on which he was ordered to be discharged.

arguments.court_reasoning: Written statement already filed controverting facts; matter pending since 1961, no remand needed

arguments.claim: For s.33(2)(b) approval, tribunal to check if enquiry proper, action bona fide, not due to victimisation or unfair labour practice

anchor.surface_text: all that the tribunal has to see when dealing with an application under s. 33 2   b  is whether the employer had conducted the enquiry properly and whether the action taken or proposed to be taken was bona fide and not due to victimisation or unfair labour practice.

arguments.claim: Enquiry properly conducted; no evidence of impropriety, victimisation or unfair labour practice

anchor.surface_text: We have been taken through the enquiry papers and we are of opinion that there is nothing in them to show that the enquiry was not properly conducted. Nor is there anything to show that the respondent was victimised or the proposed action is the result of any unfair labour practice.

arguments.claim: Enquiry held in utter disregard of natural justice rules and respondent victimised

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the respondent said in his written statement that the enquiry was merely a pretence of an enquiry and was held in utter disregard of the rules of natural justice and also that he had been victimised.

arguments.court_reasoning: No particulars of how unfair; enquiry papers show fair, proper, full opportunity to defend

arguments.claim: Enquiry fair, proper, in accordance with natural justice; full opportunity to defend; no victimisation

holdings.text: The labour court was wrong in holding that an application under s. 33(2)(b) made for approval of proposed action before actual discharge is not maintainable

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the labour court was wrong in holding that an application made by an employer under s. 33  2   b  for approval of the action he proposes to take is not entertainable and that such an application must necessarily be made after the action of which approval is sought is taken.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Misinterpretation of Strawboard case; s.33(2)(b) does not mandate application only after action; nothing prohibits pre-action application which is even more favourable to employee

holdings.text: The view of the labour court that the application by the appellant in the present case was not maintainable must fail

anchor.surface_text: The view of the labour court therefore that the application by the appellant in the present case was not maintainable must fail. This brings us to the question whether approval should be granted to the action proposed to be taken by the appellant-bank.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of clarified interpretation of s.33(2)(b) to facts

holdings.text: No remand to labour court is required despite respondent's absence due to illness

anchor.surface_text: We find however that the respondent had filed a written statement in reply to the banks application in which he controverted the facts on which he was ordered to be discharged. Considering that the matter has been pending since 1961 we do not think that this is a case where a remand is called for.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Respondent already filed written statement controverting facts; long pendency since 1961

holdings.text: All that the tribunal has to see in an application under s.33(2)(b) is whether the enquiry was properly conducted and the action bona fide without victimisation or unfair labour practice

anchor.surface_text: all that the tribunal has to see when dealing with an application under s. 33 2   b  is whether the employer had conducted the enquiry properly and whether the action taken or proposed to be taken was bona fide and not due to victimisation or unfair labour practice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Established test from prior cases applied here

anchor.surface_text: We have been taken through the enquiry papers and we are of opinion that there is nothing in them to show that the enquiry was not properly conducted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Review of enquiry papers reveals no impropriety

holdings.text: The proposed action was bona fide and not due to victimisation or unfair labour practice

anchor.surface_text: Nor is there anything to show that the respondent was victimised or the proposed action is the result of any unfair labour practice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence in papers or otherwise indicating mala fides

holdings.text: The enquiry was fair and proper, in accordance with natural justice, with full opportunity to defend; no victimisation
holdings.reasoning_summary: Respondent's vague allegations lack particulars; papers confirm fairness

holdings.text: Approval under s.33(2)(b) is granted to the bank's proposed action
holdings.reasoning_summary: All conditions for approval satisfied: proper enquiry, bona fide action, no victimisation/unfair practice
